hints.content: Start by understanding the concept of a vertical area. Remember that a vertical area is defined by two x-coordinates and extends infinitely along the y-axis. The area does not include points that lie on the edges.
Consider how you can represent the points in a way that makes it easy to find gaps between them. Sorting the points based on their x-coordinates might be a good first step.
After sorting the points by their x-coordinates, look at the differences between consecutive x-coordinates. This will help you identify potential vertical areas.
Remember that the width of the vertical area is defined as the difference between two x-coordinates minus 1. This accounts for the fact that points on the edges are not included.
When calculating the width between two points, ensure that you are only considering pairs of points that are consecutive after sorting. This will help you find the widest gaps.
Think about edge cases where all points have the same x-coordinate. In such cases, there will be no vertical area, so your solution should handle this gracefully.
As you calculate the widths, keep track of the maximum width found so far. You may want to initialize this to zero before starting the comparisons.
If you encounter two points with the same x-coordinate, remember that they do not contribute to the width of a vertical area. You should skip these points when calculating gaps.
Make sure to return the maximum width found after checking all pairs of consecutive points. This will be your final answer.
To summarize, sort the points by x-coordinates, calculate the gaps between consecutive points, and return the maximum gap minus one. Ensure to handle edge cases appropriately.

questionNotes: Points are given as pairs [xi, yi] where 0 <= xi, yi <= 10^9.
Points on the edge of the vertical area are not included in the area.
Return the maximum width of the vertical area.
